finding: The procedure was performed by Dr.  and Dr. . Dr. , the Attending Radiologist, was present during the entire procedure. Dr.   reviewed this case. The left arm was prepped in a sterile fashion. The basilic vein was localized by ultrasound and was patent and compressible. Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine was achieved overlying the site of entry. The basilic vein was then entered under ultrasonographic guidance with a 21- gauge access needle. Hardcopies of the ultrasound images were obtained. A 0.018 guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the superior vena cava. Based on the markers on the guidewire, it was determined that a length of 46 cm would be suitable for this PICC line. The PICC line was trimmed to length and advanced over a 4- French introducer sheath under fluoroscopic guidance into the superior vena cava. The sheath was then removed. The catheter was flushed. Final chest x- ray was obtained and determined the position of the tip of the PICC line at the junction of the SVC and right atrium. The line is ready for use. A StatLock was applied and the line was heplocked. There were no immediate complications.
validation_impression: Successful placement of a 46-cm single lumen PICC line with the tip in the superior vena cava, ready for use.

finding: The procedure was performed by Dr.   and Dr. . Dr. , the attending radiologist, was present and supervising throughout the procedure. After risks and benefits were explained to the patient's family, written informed consent was obtained. The patient was placed on the angiographic table in the left lateral decubitus position. The right flank was prepped and draped in a standard sterile fashion. 5 cc of 1% lidocaine was applied for local anesthesia. A 0.018 guidewire was used to advance through the preexisting track under fluoroscopic guidance with the tip in the renal pelvis. A bright tip sheath was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected through the sheath, which confirmed the tip of the sheath was in the right renal pelvis. A nephrostogram was performed and demonstrated marked hydronephrosis and no opacification of the ureter. An 8- French nephrostomy tube was then placed over the wire after the sheath was removed. The pigtail was locked in the right renal pelvis. Contrast was injected, which confirmed the appropriate position of the nephrostomy tube. The tube was connected with an external drainage bag. The patient tolerated the procedure well, and there were no immediate complications.
validation_impression: Successful placement of a right nephrostomy tube through the preexisting track with the pigtail formed in the right renal pelvis.

finding: This procedure was performed by Dr.   and Dr.  . Dr. , the staff radiologist, was present and supervising the entire procedure. The patient was placed supine on the angiography table. A limited ultrasound examination of the right upper extremity revealed several diminutive but patent brachial veins with no basilic vein present. A limited ultrasound examination of the left upper extremity was then performed revealing a thrombosed basilic vein with a patent and compressible brachial vein. The left upper extremity was then prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion. The skin and subcutaneous tissues were anesthetized with 5 cc of 1% lidocaine. Using ultrasound guidance, the left brachial vein was accessed with a 21-gauge micropuncture needle. Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained, before and after establishing an access. A standard 0.018 guide wire was advanced through the access needle into the left subclavian vein but was unable to be passed centrally. At this time, the skin entry site was incised with a #11 blade scalpel. The access needle was exchanged for a 5-French micropuncture sheath with inner dilator. A 0.018 Glidewire was passed through the micropuncture sheath, beyond the area of obstruction, into the right heart. After the inner dilator was removed, an attempt was made to advance the dual-lumen PICC line over the Glidewire into the superior vena cava. However, resistance was encountered at the left subclavian vein, presumably due to near-complete obstruction. The catheter was then removed, trimmed to a length of 20 cm, and advanced over the Glidewire through the peel-away sheath into the left axillary vein for midline placement using flouroscopic guidance. The Glidewire was removed, followed by the peel- away sheath. The catheter was flushed, capped, and heplocked. It was secured to the skin using a StatLock device. A final fluoroscopic spot film was obtained, demonstrating the tip of the midline catheter to be present in the left axillary vein. COMPLICATIONS: None. MEDICATIONS: 1% lidocaine.
validation_impression: (Over)  8:45 AM PICC LINE PLACMENT SCH Clip #  Reason: please place PICC Admitting Diagnosis: FEVER Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 10 ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont) 1) Left upper extremity limited ultrasound examination revealed a thrombosed basilic vein with a patent and compressible brachial vein. 2) Near-complete occlusion of the left subclavian vein. 3) Successful placement of a 20-cm 5-French dual-lumen midline catheter via the left brachial vein. The tip of the catheter is present in the left axillary vein. The catheter is ready for immediate use.

finding: The procedure was performed by Drs.  and , the attending radiologist who was present and supervising throughout the procedure. After the risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the patient, written informed consent was obtained. The patient was placed supine on the angiography table. The area around the existing J tube was prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion. The end of the patient's percutaneous jejunostomy tube was then cut and a 0.035 guide wire was advanced into the jejunum. The old J tube was then removed and exchanged for a 12 French introducer sheath. Inspection of the old tube revealed multiple blocked side holes with the exception of the most proximal side holes. Opacification of the jejunum was then performed with injection of Optiray contrast material through the introducer sheath. This revealed mildly dilated loops of small bowel diffusely but with peristalsis and normal antegrade flow. A 4 French catheter was then advanced into the more distal jejunum and subsequently injected with contrast material. This revealed no transition point more distally. The catheter was then removed. The introducer sheath was then exchanged for a 35 cm long 14 French non-latex catheter. The guide wire was then removed. A pig-tail was formed, securing the catheter. After placement, contrast material was injected and a KUB was obtained. It demonstrates the tube to be in proper location within the jejunum. The jejunostomy tube was then secured to the skin with suture material. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate post procedural complications. MEDICATIONS: 5 cc of 1% lidocaine for local anesthesia. 50 mcg of Fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were used for conscious sedation.

finding: After the risks and benefits were explained to the patient, written informed consent was obtained. The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table. A preprocedure timeout was obtained to confirm the patient's name, procedure, and the site. The right groin was prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion. Combining palpatory technique and fluoroscopic guidance, a 19-gauge single-wall arterial puncture needle was used to access the right femoral artery. A 0.035 Bentson guidewire was then placed through the needle under fluoroscopic guidance. The needle was exchanged for a 5-French sheath with inner dilator. After the inner dilator was removed, the sheath was connected with a continueous sidearm flush. A C2 catheter was then placed over the wire. After the wire was removed, the C2 catheter was used to subsequently engage the origin of the superior (SMA) and inferior () mesenteric arteries. Selective superior mesenteric arteriogram, inferior mesenteric arteriogram and superselective arteriogram of several small branches of the SMA were performed. Active bleeding was confirmed at the hepatic flexure, best accessed through a middle colic branch coming off the proximal superior mesenteric artery. Additional selective and superselective angiograms of the SMA and its branches were performed to precise the anatomy and helped determining the origin of the middle colic branch feeding the bleeding area. This branch was (Over)  11:17 AM MESENTERIC Clip #  Reason: mesenteric angiogram - hepatic flexure bleed seen on tagged Admitting Diagnosis: LOWER GI BLEED Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 330 ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont) arising at right angle from the right lateral side of the proximal SMA, then followed an almost circular course towards the left side before eventually continuing as the marginal artery of , located in an axial transverse plane. Based on the diagnostic findings, the decision was made to proceed as planned with superselective embolization. A 3 French Tracker microcatheter was then placed coaxially through the C2 catheter. After a few unsuccessful attempts with the regular wire, the marginal artery of  could be successfully accessed by using a "golden" 0.018 Glidewire. The microcatheter could be advanced over this wire up to just beyond the hepatic flexure, and six microcoils (0.018 x 2 mm x 1 cm) were deployed successively two by two at the level of margin artery while pulling back progressively the mirocatheter. Post-procedure arteriogram was performed which demonstrated no evidence of residual extravasation of contrast and good residual collateral flow at the hepatic flexure, provided by a collateral of the marginal artery arising around the midline and following it parallel towards the right upper quadrant. The microcatheter and C2 catheter were then removed. The sheath was removed. Hemostasis was achieved by direct manual groin pressure for 20 minutes. COMPLICATIONS: The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. MEDICATION: During the procedure, totals of 1 mg Versed and 125 mg fentanyl were given in divided intravenous doses for conscious sedation under continuous monitoring of the patient's hemodynamic parameters. 10 cc of 1% lidocaine was given subcutaneously for local anesthesia. Approximately 330 cc of Optiray 320 contrast was used intraarterially during the procedure.
validation_impression: 1. Active bleeding was confirmed angiographically at the hepatic flexure, best accessed through a middle colic branch coming off the proximal superior mesenteric artery. 2. Successful embolization of the branch of middle colic artery with 6 microcoils at the level of marginal artery with good residual collateral flow at the end of the procedure and cessation of angiographic extravasation.
generated_impression: Selective SMA arteriogram demonstrated no large branches to the splenic flexure area, but active bleeding was confirmed at the hepatic flexure through a middle colic branch of the proximal SMA.

An 0.035 guidewire was then advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the SVC. After an appropriate length of 20 cm catheter was determined, the tract was serially dilated over a guidewire. A 12.5 French temporary dialysis catheter was inserted over the guidewire through the left internal jugular vein. A final chest X-ray documents the dialysis catheter tip to be at the SVC-right atrial junction. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications. The dialysis catheter was secured to the skin surface by suturing and dressing.

finding: After explaining the risks and benefits of the procedure, written informed consent was obtained. The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table. A preprocedure timeout was performed verying the patient's identity and the procedure to be performed.   nasogastric tube was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the antrum of the stomach. The stomach was then insufflated with air. The abdomen was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A suitable site for percutaneous gastrostomy was selected in the left upper abdomen. The area was anesthetized with approximately 10 cc of 1% lidocaine. Using a 19 gauge needle, two T- fasteners were advanced into the stomach under continuous fluoroscopic guidance, anchoring the stomach to the anterior abdominal wall. The same 19 gauge needle was then used to access the stomach. A 0.035 Bentson guidewire was then advanced into the stomach and the needle was removed after making a skin . Using a Kumpe catheter and a 0.035 angled glidewire, the catheter and wire were advanced into a postpyloric position. The 0.035 glidewire was removed and exchanged for a 0.035 superstiff Amplatz wire. The Kumpe catheter was removed. The tract was serially dilated using 8, 10, and 12 Fr dilators. The 14 Fr peelaway sheath was then advanced into the stomach. The inner dilator was removed and a 14 Fr  GJ tube was advanced over the wire as the peelaway sheath was removed. The wire was then removed, and the pigtail was deployed in the duodenum. Injection of 10 cc of Conray contrast material verified correct positioning, as documented by a final fluoroscopic spot image. The catheter was secured to the skin using a Flexitrack. COMPLICATIONS: None. CONTRAST/MEDICATIONS: 15 cc of Conray contrast material, 1% lidocaine locally (10 cc). 75 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were given in divided doses under continuous hemodynamic monitoring by Radiology nursing staff for (Over)  7:32 AM PERC G/G-J TUBE PLMT Clip #  Reason: dysphagia/needs g/j tube/risk for aspiration Contrast: CONRAY Amt: 25 ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont) conscious sedation.
validation_impression: Successful placement of a 14 Fr  GJ tube. The tip is located well beyond the ligament of Treitz in the jejunum. Tube care and usage instructions were sent with the patient to the rehabilitation facility.

finding: The procedure was performed by Drs.  and  , the attending physician,  was present and supervising. The patient's left upper arm was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. finding: After the risks, benefits and alternatives of the proposed procedure were explained to the  healthcare proxy, informed consent was obtained. The patient was taken to the angiography suite and placed in the supine position. The abdomen was prepped and draped in usual sterile fashion. A preprocedure timeout was performed. Next, air was insufflated into the stomach via the indwelling nasogastric tube under fluoroscopic monitoring. The patient was given 1 mg of glucagon to decrease the rate of peristalsis. Once a safe adequate window for our approach was determined under fluoroscopy, the skin was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine over the proposed puncture site. Next, three T- fasteners were placed using a  safety T-kit. Contrast was injected during each placement to ensure intraluminal position. Next, an introducer needle was placed between the three T-fasteners into the gastric lumen and the needle was exchanged for a 0.035  wire. A 5 French  Tip sheath was then advanced over the wire and into the stomach lumen to gain access. Several attempts were made to navigate in a post-pyloric position using a glidewire and Kumpe catheter without success. A decision was made to place a gastrostomy tube. The 0.035 wire was then exchanged for a stiff Amplatz wire which was advanced into the (Over)  12:18 PM PERC G/J TUBE CHECK Clip #  Reason: PEG tube placement Admitting Diagnosis: S/P FALL Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 45 ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont) gastric antrum. The 5 French sheath was then removed over the wire. Following serial dilatation of the tract up to 12 French, a 12 French Wills-  gastrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and positioned with its tip in the gastric lumen under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the catheter loop was formed and locked in the stomach. Injection of a small amount of contrast material confirmed the tip to be located in the gastric antrum. The catheter was secured to the skin with 0 silk suture and a StatLock device. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications.
validation_impression: Successful placement of a 12 French Wills- gastrostomy tube via a percutaneous approach. The tube may be used in 24 hours if aspirates are clear and the patient is free of abdominal pain. The T- fasteners will fall out on their own in approximately six weeks.

finding: After the risks, benefits and alternatives of the proposed procedure as well as those of conscious sedation were thoroughly explained to the patient via a Russian interpreter, informed consent was informed. Patient was taken to the angiography suite and placed in the left lateral decubitus position. The right flank was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. A preprocedure timeout was performed. Next, a Chiba needle was used to access a posterior calix using ultrasound guidance. Once adequate urine flow was noted from the needle, a glidewire was passed through the needle and into the proximal ureter. Of note, thick urine was obtained from the needle during the procedure and sent for culture. A skin  was made over the needle and the needle was then removed. An AccuStick introducer system was then placed over the wire and positioned at the level of the calix. The wire was then removed and contrast was injected confirming satisfactory position within the posterior lateral calix. This was also confirmed with air injection noting the air was rising to the level of the posterior calix where needle position was located. Given these findings, the AccuStick sheaths were then positioned over the wire and coiled in the proximal ureter. The glidewire was then exchanged for a 0.035 Amplatz wire. The AccuStick system was then removed and an 8 French percutaneous nephrostomy tube was positioned over the wire and into the renal pelvis. The wire was removed and the tube was then formed and locked under fluoroscopic monitoring. 0 silk suture was used to secure the tube in place along with a StatLock. A sterile dressing was applied. (Over)  5:16 PM PERC NEPHROSTO Clip #  Reason: please place percutaneous nephrostomy tube Admitting Diagnosis: URINARY TRACT INFECTION;PYELONEP ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont) Of note, very minimal amounts of contrast were seen to pass distal to the existing obstructive proximal ureteral stone during the procedure. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

finding: The risks and benefits were explained to the patient and consent was obtained. The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table and the right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Ultrasound examination of the right neck was performed and showed occlusion of the right internal jugular vein. Since the patient has a right subclavian vein access with triple lumen catheter in place, the catheter site was further prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A 0.035  wire was placed through the catheter with its tip into the middle hepatic vein. The catheter was removed and a 7 french bright tipped sheath placed over the wire into the middle hepatic vein. Injection of nonionic contrast showed patent middle hepatic vein. The wire was removed and a 5 french occlusion balloon catheter was placed into the distal middle hepatic vein and the balloon was inflated. Wedge hepatic portal pressure was measured and was 18 mm of Mercury and the right atrial pressure was measured thereafter showing a mean pressure of 13 mm of Mercury with a gradient of 5 mm of mercury. The catheter was removed and biopsy forceps were placed through the sheath into the middle hepatic vein and a total of three samples of hepatic tissue were obtained. At the end of the procedure   wire was placed through the sheath into the IVC and the sheath was removed. A 7 french, 16 cm long triple lumen catheter was placed over the wire with its tip in the superior vena cava. The catheter was flushed and secured to the skin using two 0 Prolene sutures. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no complications. MEDICATIONS: 1 mg of Versed and 15 mcg of fentanyl were given in small divided doses during the procedure.

finding: After risks and benefits of procedure as well as anesthesia were explained, informed consent was obtained. The patient was brought to angiography suite and placed supine on imaging table. The right side of the abdomen was prepared and draped in usual sterile fashion. A scout image demonstrated the existing internal-external biliary draining catheter was in place. A 6 French -Tip sheath was then placed over the wire into the common bile duct. After the inner stiffener of the sheath was removed, the sheath was then pulled back with its tip located in the right hepatic duct. finding: The procedure was performed by Dr.  and Dr. , present and supervising throughout. The left upper quadrant was prepped in sterile fashion. Written consent was obtained prior to proceeding. Pertinent history includes prior enterectomy with Roux en Y gastrojejunostomy for a perforated ulcer 12 years ago. The stomach was visible under fluoroscopy, confirmed to be anterior with lateral projection and inflated nicely with air via the NG tube. An appropriate spot was chosen on the skin below the costochondral margin on the left, and lidocaine was infiltrated. The stomach was entered percutaneously with a long needle and a fastener was inserted. A second fastener was inserted adjacent to this under fluoroscopic guidance in the same way.   was made in the skin between these two, and the needle was advanced again for the third time into the stomach. A guide wire was passed through the needle and the needle was exchanged for a 4 FR introducer sheath. The guide wire was manipulated into the jejunum. Serial dilatations were then performed after switching for an Amplatz wire. A 14 FR  catheter GJ catheter was then positioned with its pigtail formed in the jejunum. Its position was confirmed by injection of water soluble contrast demonstrating opacification of small bowel loops. There were no immediate post procedure complications. The fasteners should be removed in 7 to 10 days as instructed in the orders placed in POE.
validation_impression: Successful placement of percutaneous GJ-tube.
generated_impression: Successful placement of a percutaneous gastrojejunostomy tube with its tip in the stomach and proximal jejunum, without immediate complications.

finding: The procedure was described to the patient and informed consent was obtained. The pre-existing 8 French left biliary drainage catheter was cleansed and draped in sterile fashion, and an antegrade cholangiogram was performed. This demonstrated significant amount of filling defect in the common duct, just proximal to the anastomosis, most likely representing biliary sludge. The right and left intrahepatic ducts are mild to moderately dilated. The catheter appears in good position. A 0.035 Amplatz straight wire was advanced without difficult through the existing catheter, and the catheter was exchanged for a 7 French, 23-cm bright-tip sheath. An antegrade cholangiogram was repeated, demonstrating a high-grade smooth focal stricture at the anastomosis. Both the common hepatic duct and cystic duct are dilated and have a common origin. The stricture was then dilated using an 8-mm x 4 cm balloon, and during the dilatation, no waist was demonstrated and the patient experienced no pain. An antegrade cholangiogram was repeated following dilatation, demonstrating no significant change in the focal narrowing. This was followed by initially a 10-mm and then 12-mm balloon. The findings most likely represent ischemic stricture at the anastomosis and do not appear to be due to extrinsic depression. The previously placed 8 French biliary drain was upsized to 10 French today, placing the internal-external drain in the small bowel. The tube was capped for internal drainage. The case and findings were discussed with Dr.  following the study, and it was decided to perform a repeat cholangiogram in four weeks. COMPLICATIONS: None.

finding: After informed consent was obtained from the  healthcare proxy, the patient was placed supine on the angiographic table and the right neck was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. Using ultrasonographic guidance and after injection of 5 mL of 1% lidocaine, a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the right internal jugular vein under ultrasonographic guidance. Hard copies of the images before and after the venopuncture were obtained. A 0.018 guidewire was then advanced through the needle up to the level of the distal SVC under fluoroscopic guidance and the needle was then exchanged for 4.5 French micropuncture sheath. The wire was exchanged for a 0.035  wire and progressive dilation of the tract was performed with 12 French and 14 French dilators. A 20-cm hemodialysis double- lumen catheter was placed over the wire with tip in the right atrium and the wire removed. The line was flushed, heplocked and statlocked and the catheter was sutured to the skin with 0 silk sutures. A dressing was applied. Final fluoroscopic image of the chest demonstrates the tip of the catheter to be located in the right atrium. The patient tolerated the procedure well.
validation_impression: Successful placement of a 14.5-French, 20-cm long, double-lumen dialysis catheter via the right internal jugular vein. The tip of the catheter is in the right atrium, and the line is ready for use.

finding: A preprocedural timeout was performed to confirm the patient's identity and the type of procedure to be performed. The left upper extremity was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Ultrasound was used to identify the left brachial vein which was patent and compressible. After injection of 4 cc of 1% lidocaine, a 21-gauge needle was advanced under ultrasound guidance into the left brachial vein. Hardcopy ultrasound images were obtained before and after venous access documenting patency. A 0.018 guidewire was then advanced through the needle to the distal SVC. The needle was then exchanged for a 4.5 French micropuncture sheath. A 5 French double- lumen PICC catheter was then advanced through the sheath under fluoroscopic guidance into the mid/distal SVC. The peel-away sheath and wire were then removed. A final fluoroscopic spot image of the chest demonstrates the tip of the PICC catheter to be located in the mid/distal SVC. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate post-procedure complications. The catheter was flushed and statlocked in appropriate position.
validation_impression: Successful placement of 5 French double-lumen PICC catheter via the left brachial vein. The line is now ready for use.
generated_impression: Successful placement of a 5 French double-lumen PICC catheter via the left brachial vein, with the tip located in the mid/distal SVC. The patient tolerated the procedure well and the catheter is ready for use.

finding: The patient was placed supine on the angiography table. No images were available from outside ultrasound. Ultrasound of the external iliacs/superficial femoral veins was performed. It showed decreased compressibility of the proximal right superficial femoral vein as well as distal right external iliac vein. Therefore, decision was made to gain access through the left common femoral vein. Under ultrasonographic guidance, access was gained to the left common femoral vein with a 19-gauge needle. A 0.035  guide wire was advanced through the needle into the inferior vena . The needle was removed over the wire and a 5-French sheath was introduced. A 4-French Omni Flush catheter was then advanced over the wire into the inferior vena . Inferior cavogram was obtained. It showed a single inferior vena ,  image suggestive of possible filling defect in the region of the right common iliac vein. The catheter was then advanced up and a new more proximal cavogram was obtained. It showed inflow defects documenting the level of the renal arteries and therefore allowing planning of the adequate site for deployment of the IVC filter. Catheter and sheath were removed over the wire and a 9-French filter deployment sheath was advanced over the wire into the inferior vena . Permanent Vena Tech filter was then advanced through the sheath under fluoroscopic guidance and was precisely deployed below the renal veins. Final abdominal x-ray was obtained documenting position and adequate deployment of the IVC filter. The sheath was removed and pressure was held until hemostasis was achieved. COMPLICATIONS: There were no immediate complications. (Over)  7:29 AM IVC GRAM/FILTER Clip #  Reason: placement of IVC filter Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 50 ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont)
validation_impression: Successful placement of a permanent inferior vena  filter below the renal veins.

finding: This procedure was performed by Drs.  and , the Attending Physician who was present and supervising throughout. The patient's right upper chest was prepped and draped. The dialysis catheter sutures were cut. 1% lidocaine was infused along the tunnel tract. The cuff was freed with blunt dissection using   clamp. The right IJ tunneled catheter was subsequently removed. Pressure was held at the IJ puncture site until hemostasis was achieved. The tip of the catheter was sent for culture. The patient's left neck was subsequently prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. After infusion of 1% lidocaine, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a 21-gauge needle under ultrasonographic guidance. Hard-copy ultrasound images were obtained before and after access. A 0.018 wire was advanced into the SVC. The puncture needle was exchanged for a 4- French catheter. The 0.018 wire and inner dilator were removed and a 0.035 wire was advanced through the SVC into the IVC. The tract was progressively dilated with 7-, 10, 12- and 14-French dilators. This was somewhat difficult due to the patient's existing scar tissues and blunt and sharp dissection was required for the dilatation. After the serial dilation, a 20-cm 14-French temporary dialysis catheter was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire and the inner dilator were removed. The line was flushed and heplocked and secured with 2-0 nylon sutures. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate post-procedure complications. A final film was obtained showing absence of a pneumothorax.
validation_impression: 1) Removal of right IJ tunneled dialysis catheter. Line tip sent for culture. 2) Successful placement of left 20-cm 14-French temporary dialysis catheter via internal jugular vein access with tip in distal SVC. Line is ready for use. finding: The risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the patient and written informed consent was obtained. A preprocedural timeout confirmed the patient identity and the type of procedure to be performed. Ultrasound of both internal jugular veins demonstrated occlusive thrombus. The right common femoral vein was patent and thus the right groin was sterilely prepped and draped. The right femoral vein was then accessed under ultrasound guirdance using a 4.5 French micropuncture set. Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and after venous access documenting vessel patency. An angiodynamics 14.5 French 55 cm hemodialysis set was chosen. The catheter was laid out to approximate a subcutaneous tract, after which the potential tract was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine local anesthesia with epinephrine. Tract was created using blunt dissection. The micropuncture set was then replaced with an Amplatz wire after which the tract was progressively dilated. A peel-away sheath introducer was placed followed by placement of the catheter under fluoroscopic guidance. The peel- away sheath and wire were then removed. The site was closed with subcutaneous interrupted sutures. Irrigation was performed with antibiotic solution. Post-procedure fluoroscopic images document the tip of the catheter to be in the right atrial/IVC junction. Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of fentanyl and Versed throughout the intra-service time of 50 minutes, during which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored.
validation_impression: Successful placement of right femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter with tip in the IVC/right atrial junction. The port is ready for use. (Over)  1:34 PM TUNNELLED CATH PLACE SCH Clip #  Reason: left tunneled ij cath for hd Admitting Diagnosis: ACUTE RENAL FAILURE ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont)

finding: The procedure was performed by Dr. with Dr. , the attending physician who was present and supervising. Informed consent was obtained and preprocedure timeout was performed. Ultrasonographic examination of the right internal jugular vein demonstrated occlusion of the right IJ. The patient's left neck was subsequently prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. After infusion of 1% lidocaine, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a 21-gauge needle under ultrasonographic guidance. Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and after access. An 0.018 wire was advanced into the SVC under flouroscopic guidance. Measurements were obtained and it was determined that a 24 cm catheter would be appropriate. After exchanging for an 035 wire, the tract was progressively dilated with 12- and 14-French dilators. A 24 cm 14- French temporary dialysis catheter was subsequently advanced over the wire. The line was flushed and hep-locked and secured with 0 silk sutures. Final chest image demonstrated appropriate positioning of the catheter tip in the right atrium. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there are no immediate post-procedure complications.
validation_impression: Successful placement of left IJ 24 cm 14-French temporary dialysis catheter with tip in the right atrium. The line is ready for use. 2. Occlusion of the right internal jugular vein.

finding: Written, informed consent was obtained after the risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the patient. The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table. A preprocedure timeout confirmed the name of the patient, date of birth, and side and type of procedure to be performed. The right groin was prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion. The skin and subcutaneous tissues were infiltrated with approximately 10 cc of 1% lidocaine for local anesthesia. The right common femoral pulse was palpable and arterial puncture was achieved. A  guide wire was advanced into the abdominal aorta under fluoroscopy. The access needle was removed over the wire and exchanged for a 5 French vascular sheath. A 4 French Omniflush catheter was employed to obtain an abdominal and pelvic aortogram. These initial images showed a blush within the medial aspect of the right pelvis at the level of the right superior pubic ramus. Based upon the diagnostic findings, it was decided the patient would benefit from and was a good candidate for embolization. Therefore, a selective right internal iliac arteriogram was obtained through a 5 French pudendal catheter. This catheter again showed the right medial pelvic blush. A (Over)  10:49 PM ILIAC Clip #  Reason: Embolization of branch of iliac a Admitting Diagnosis: S/P FALL Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 208 ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont) selective inferior gluteal arteriogram was then obtained showing the same findings. The inferior gluteal artery, supplying the bleeding area was selectively catheterized with a Renegade microcatheter. Branch embolization of the was performed with gelfoam slurry administration until stagnation of flow was achieved. A repeat pelvic aortogram showed continued active extravasation in the same region, supplied now by the right obturator artery. The bleeding branch was selctively catheterized with a microcatheter and another selective arteriogram confirmed the bleeding. This small branch was then embolized with gelfoam slurry until stagnation of flow was achieved. Post- embolization aortogram demonstrates no residual blush of contrast. Subsequently, the catheter sheath was removed and direct pressure to the right groin was applied until hemostasis was achieved. The puncture site was covered and the patient was taken to the trauma ICU. Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of 75 mcg of fentanyl and 0.5 mg of Versed throughout the total intraservice time of three hours 45 minutes during which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored. There were no immediate post-procedure complications.
validation_impression: Successful transcatheter embolization of branches of the inferior gluteal artery, as well as a small branch of the right obturator artery with Gelfoam slurry with final pelvic aortogram showing no evidence of active extravasation of contrast.

finding: Informed consent was obtained from the patient's daughter, who is the  healthcare proxy. The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table. The right groin was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. Local anesthesia was given with 8 cc of 1% lidocaine. The right common femoral vein was accessed with a 19-gauge needle using Seldinger technique under ultrasonographic guidance. An 0.035 Bentson guidewire was advanced through the needle into the inferior vena cava. The needle was removed over the wire, and a 4-French Omniflush catheter was advanced over the wire into the vena cava. Attempt was made to advance the catheter across the bifurcation, however, this was not successful. The  wire was changed for an 0.035 Glidewire, and the Omniflush catheter was advanced over the Glidewire over the bifurcation. A venogram was then performed, including an inferior vena cava, which showed a single IVC, and inflow defects corresponding to the right and left renal veins. The  wire was again advanced into the inferior vena cava. The Omniflush catheter was removed over the wire. The IVC filter sheath was advanced over the wire using fluoroscopic guidance. The Recovery filter (Bard) was then advanced through the sheath, and successfully deployed below the left of the left renal vein. A final abdominal x-ray was obtained documenting successful placement and position of the IVC filter. The sheath was then removed and pressure applied until hemostasis was achieved. COMPLICATIONS: None. (Over)  7:56 PM IVC GRAM/FILTER Clip #  Reason: Please place REMOVEABLE FILTER for bilateral PE's in patient Admitting Diagnosis: S/P FALL INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGE Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 40 ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont)

finding: Study is compared with contrast-enhanced CT examination of the chest dated . There is normal opacification of the pulmonary arterial tree through its fourth-order and more distal branches, with no evidence of pulmonary embolus. There is prominence of the main pulmonary artery, which measures 3.7 cm in diameter, as before, larger than the adjacent aorta, which may relate to underlying pulmonary hypertension. There is no definite evidence of abnormal "pruning" of the more peripheral vessels. There is normal opacification of normal caliber ascending and descending portions of the thoracic aorta, as well as the aortic arch, without evidence of dissection, ulcerated or calcified plaque or aneurysm. The adjacent abundant mediastinal fat is preserved. There is grossly normal opacification of the proximal coronary arteries with stents evident in the RCA and tandem stents in the mid-distal LAD; calcification and/or smaller caliber stent is also noted in the proximal left circumflex vessel. There is no specific evidence of occlusion of the proximal portions of the left and right coronary arteries. Noted are numerous small lymph nodes throughout the mediastinum, with a conglomerate 2.2 x 1.3 cm right paratracheal lymph node, as well as conglomerate subcarinal adenopathy, extending into the azygoesophageal recess, and bilateral hilar adenopathy. Again demonstrated are scattered pulmonary micronodules, many of which are calcified, but some of which are noncalcified, with mid- and lower lung predominance (many of the smaller nodules were demonstrated to be calcified on the previous thin-section CT images). Less well-demonstrated are the peribronchiolar opacities in the perihilar regions, with diffuse thickening of bronchovascular structures.
validation_impression: 1. No evidence of acute pulmonary embolism. There is persistent prominence of the main pulmonary artery, raising the possibility of underlying pulmonary hypertension. 2. Unremarkable appearance to the thoracic aorta, without evidence of dissection. (Over)  9:35 AM CTA CHEST W&W/O C&RECONS, NON-CORONARY Clip #  Reason: r/o aortic dissection, pe. Creatinine at OSH 1.0. Contrast: VISAPAQUE Amt: 80 ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont) 3. Status post CABG and coronary stenting, with no definite evidence of proximal right or left coronary occlusion (this study cannot exclude occlusion in more distal segments, or in the stents). 4. Numerous calcified and non-calcified pulmonary micronodules, peribronchial opacities, bronchovascular thickening and mediastinal and hilar adenopathy. These findings may be seen with underlying sarcoidosis (superimposed on background prior granulomatous infection), which should be correlated with clinical data. finding: The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table. The left arm was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. Ultrasound confirmed the left brachial vein to be patent and compressed. 5 cc of 1% lidocaine was applied for local anesthesia. Using ultrasound guidance, a 21 gauge needle was used to access the left brachial vein. Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and after venous access documenting access. A 0.018 guidewire was placed through the needle under fluoroscopic guidance and the tip was advanced into the superior vena cava. The needle was exchanged for a 4 French peel-away sheath. The length of the PICC was measured to be 41 cm based on the markings on the wire. After the inner dilator was removed, a single lumen PICC was placed over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance with the tip in the superior vena cava. The peel-away sheath and the wire were removed. The lumen was flushed and secured to the skin with statlock and covered with sterile Tegaderm. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate post-procedure complications.
validation_impression: Successful placement of a 41 cm single lumen PICC in the left brachial vein with the tip in the superior vena cava. The line is ready for use.
generated_impression: Successful placement of a 41-cm single lumen PICC through the left brachial vein with the tip in the superior vena cava. The line is ready to use.

finding: CT OF THE CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST: Incidental note is made of a calcified right thyroid lobe nodule measuring 1.2 x 1.3 cm. There is a 4.9 x 5.5 mm nodule within the right upper lobe. There is prominence to the pulmonary vasculature bilaterally with subtle ground-glass opacification, which can be seen in cases of fluid overload. There are no dense consolidations, pleural effusions or pericardial effusions. CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH AND WITHOUT IV CONTRAST: The liver, spleen, pancreas, adrenal glands are unremarkable. The native kidneys are atrophic bilaterally. There is subtle thickening of the antrum of the stomach, which does open on delayed scan, however remains slightly thickened. Please correlate with prior endoscopy. The gallbladder is contracted. There is no intra-abdominal free air or free fluid. No significant retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy is appreciated. Oral contrast has been administered and is seen within loops of small bowel, as well as proximal colon. There is no evidence of bowel obstruction. There is an area of small bowel within the mid abdomen, seen best on Image 74, Series 4, that demonstrates mild bowel wall thickening and dilatation. CT PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST: There are multiple low-density masses present within a pelvic kidney. The largest of these masses measures 4.8 x 3.6 cm. There are additional smaller low-density masses at the lower pole of this kidney. These measure approximately 36 Hounsfield units. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis. There is a minimal amount of right perinephric stranding adjacent to the transplanted kidney. Additionally, there is stranding within the superficial tissue within the right lower abdomen, consistent with surgical incision site. There is a small amount of low- density pelvic free fluid. The urinary bladder and uterus are unremarkable. (Over)  9:50 AM CT CHEST W/CONTRAST; CT ABD W&W/O C Clip #  CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST Reason: Please eval for chest/abdominal malignancy in this transplan Field of view: 40 Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100 ______________________________________________________________________________ FINAL REPORT (Cont) There is a 1.3 x .8 cm right perirectal lymph node. BONE WINDOWS: There are no suspicious osseous lesions.
validation_impression: 1. There are multiple hypodense masses within the transplanted kidney. This is not specific but can be seen in conditions such as lymphoma of the kidney or infectious conditions such as pyelonephritis. 2. Right upper lobe lung nodule. 3. Findings within the lung parenchyma suggestive of volume overload. 4. Right calcified thyroid lobe nodule. 5. Small amount of thickening of the antrum of the stomach. Please correlate with recent endoscopy. 6. There is focal bowel wall thickening of a loop of small bowel seen within the mid abdomen. This can be seen in infiltrative conditions, such as lymphoproliferative disorders.
generated_impression: Impression: A 4.8 x 3.6 cm low-density mass is present within a pelvic kidney with no evidence of hydronephrosis. There are additional smaller masses at the lower pole of this kidney. No significant retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy is appreciated.

finding: An initial fluoroscopic image demonstrated the existing single-lumen PICC via a right antecubital vein to be malpositioned in the right internal jugular vein. The patient's right arm was prepped and draped in usual sterile fashion. The existing indwelling wire was removed from the PICC. A new 0.018 guidewire was advanced through the PICC and into the superior vena cava using fluoroscopic guidance. The PICC was removed over the wire and a 4.5-French peel- away sheath placed. Based on the markers on the wire, a length of 50 cm was deemed appropriate for the new PICC. A new double-lumen PICC was trimmed to length and advanced over the wire into the SVC using fluoroscopic guidance. finding: The risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the  healthcare proxy and informed consent was obtained. The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging table. The abdomen and indwelling feeding tube was prepped and draped in usual sterile fashion. A preprocedure timeout was performed to confirm the identity of the patient by name, medical record number, date of birth, and the nature of the procedure to be performed. Initial scout image demonstrates tip of GJ tube positioned over the mid abdomen. Small amount of contrast was injected into the feeding tube, which revealed the tip of the catheter to be located in the stomach. A 0.035  wire was advanced through the indwelling feeding tube into the stomach and the feeding tube was removed. Using a Kumpe catheter, the guidewire was directed into the jejunum to the level of the ligament of treitz. The  wire was replaced for an Amplatz wire over which a new 14 French  GJ tube was advanced. The wire was removed and the loop formed in the duodenum. Injection of contrast revealed the tip of the new feeding tube to be located within the jejunum. The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
validation_impression: Uncomplicated exchange of 14 French  GJ tube. Tip of feeding tube is located within the jejunum. The feeding tube is ready to use.
generated_impression: Impression: Uncomplicated exchange of GJ tube, tip located in jejunum.
